message_1: A set of twins, A and B, are born simultaneously. Twin A remains on Earth, while Twin B travels through space at close to the speed of light and then returns to Earth. How much time has passed for each twin, and how much older is one twin than the other?
message_2:
This is a classic example of the Twin Paradox in the context of special relativity. In order to solve this problem, we need to know the exact speed at which Twin B is traveling and the duration of the trip. However, I can provide a general explanation of the phenomenon and the expected outcome.

When Twin B travels at a speed close to the speed of light, time dilation occurs. Time dilation is a difference in the elapsed time measured by two observers due to the relative difference in their velocities. In this case, the two observers are Twin A (on Earth) and Twin B (traveling through space).

According to the time dilation formula:

Δt' = Δt / √(1 - v²/c²)

where:
- Δt' is the dilated time experienced by Twin B (the moving twin)
- Δt is the proper time experienced by Twin A (the stationary twin)
- v is the relative velocity of Twin B
- c is the speed of light

Since Twin B is traveling at a speed close to the speed of light, the factor v²/c² is close to 1, making the denominator of the fraction close to 0. As a result, the dilated time Δt' experienced by Twin B will be significantly smaller than the proper time Δt experienced by Twin A.

When Twin B returns to Earth, they will have aged less than Twin A. The exact difference in their ages will depend on the specific values of the speed and duration of the trip.
